revision.comment: Rescuing 7 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.2.7.1)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {|{{Infobox aircraft begin |name= J-20 |image= File:J-20 at Airshow China 2016.jpg |caption= J-20 flight at [[Airshow China|Airshow China 2016]] }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type= [[Stealth aircraft|Stealth]] [[air superiority fighter]] / [[multirole combat aircraft]] |national origin = [[China]] |manufacturer= [[Chengdu Aircraft Industry Group|Chengdu Aerospace Corporation]] |first flight= 11 January 2011 |introduced= 2016 |status= [[Low rate initial production]] |retired= |primary user= [[People's Liberation Army Air Force]] |more users= |number built= 8 prototypes{{cite web|url=http://www.popsci.com/6th-j-20-stealth-fighter-rolls-out-more-soon-follow |title=6th J-20 Stealth Fighter Rolls Out| work = Popular science |date=2014-12-23|accessdate= 2014-12-24}}{{cite web|url= http://mil.news.sina.com.cn/2015-11-25/0848844774.html |title= 歼20战机或已冻结设计 不会直接用俄117S发动机 |publisher= Sina | language = zh | date=2015-11-25 | place = [[China|CN]] |accessdate= 2015-11-25}} and
4 low rate initial production fighters {{ cite web|url=http://mil.news.sina.com.cn/jssd/2016-01-11/doc-ifxnkkuy7894954.shtml |title= 深度：谁是首个被歼20战机击落的对象 日印心理有阴影 |publisher= mil.news.sina.com.cn|date=2016-01-11}}{{cite news |url=http://www.defenseone.com/news/2016/07/the-d-brief-july-14-2016/129896/ |title=China’s stealth fighter jet arsenal is growing |last1=Watson |first1=Ben |last2=Peniston |first2=Bradley |date=14 July 2016 |website=www.defenseone.com |publisher=Defense One |accessdate=14 July 2016}} |program cost= |unit cost= US$110 million as of 2011Axe, David. [http://the-diplomat.com/flashpoints-blog/2011/01/31/at-what-cost-stealth/ "At What Cost Stealth?"] ''The Diplomat'', 31 January 2011. |developed from= |variants with their own articles= |developed into= }} |} The '''Chengdu J-20''' ([[wikt:歼|simplified Chinese]]: 歼-20; [[wikt:殲|traditional Chinese]]: 殲-20) is a [[Stealth aircraft|stealth]], [[twinjet]], [[fifth-generation jet fighter|fifth-generation]] fighter aircraft developed by China's [[Chengdu Aircraft Industry Group|Chengdu Aerospace Corporation]] for the [[People's Liberation Army Air Force]] (PLAAF).{{Cite web |url=http://www.defense-update.com/products/j/29122010_j-20.html |title=Chengdu J-20 – China’s 5th Generation Fighter|work=Defense Update|accessdate=23 January 2011}} The J-20 made its first flight on 11 January 2011, and started in service in 2016.{{Cite web|url= http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/11/chinese-stealth-fighter-makes-test-flight/ |title=Chinese Stealth Fighter Makes First Flight|work=Fox News|date=11 January 2011}}{{Cite web |last= Sweetman |first=William|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story.jsp?id=news/awst/2011/01/03/AW_01_03_2011_p18-279564.xml&channel=defense|title=China’s J-20 Stealth Fighter In Taxi Tests|work= [[Aviation Week]] |date=3 January 2011|accessdate=30 June 2011}}{{Cite news | language = zh |url= http://news.xinhuanet.com/mil/2009-11/09/content_12416003.htm | place = CN |title=《面对面》 对话何为荣： 中国正在研制第四代战机 |agency= [[Xinhua News Agency]] |date= 2009-11-09 | accessdate = 2 February 2013}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/hqjs/2010-02/21/content_9478920.htm | work = China daily | date = 2010-02-21 |title= 第四代战机，中国等不了十年！}} ==Development== [[File:J-20s.jpg|thumb|The two Chengdu J-20s that made its first public appearance at Airshow China 2016]] ===Origins=== The [[J-XX]] program was started in the late 1990s. A proposal from [[Chengdu Aircraft Industry Group|Chengdu Aerospace Corporation]], designated Project 718, won the PLAAF endorsement following a 2008 competition against a Shenyang proposal that was larger than the J-20.{{cite web |url= http://www.warchina.com/news/ent/2010-11-05/124805.html | date = 2010-11-05 |title=中国空军选定下一代战机由611所方案胜出 | language = zh | work = War China |accessdate=10 June 2013}} In 2009, a senior PLAAF official revealed that the first flight was expected in 2010–11, with an service entry date by 2019.{{Cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-248553676.html|title=Chinese Fifth Generation Fighter Unveiled|work=SP's Aviation|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=14 June 2015|subscription=yes|via= [[HighBeam Research]]}} On 22 December 2010, the first J-20 prototype underwent high speed [[taxiing]] tests outside the [[Chengdu Aircraft Design Institute]].{{Cite web|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2010/12/chinese-stealth-fighter-unveiled/ |title=Chinese Stealth Fighter Unveiled?|work=Australian Aviation |date= 30 December 2010}}[http://online.wsj.com/video/hub-extra-chinese-stealth-fighter-jet-video/665194B3-77F1-435F-9D9D-83E1C63AE052.html "Video: Chinese Stealth Fighter."] ''Wall Street Journal''. Retrieved 10 January 2011. ===Flight testing=== On 11 January 2011, the J-20 made its first flight, lasting about 15 minutes, with a [[Chengdu J-10S]] serving as the [[chase aircraft]].{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704428004576075042571461586.html |title=Chinese Stealth Fighter Makes First Test Flight |newspaper= The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=23 January 2011}}{{Cite web|last=Wall|first= Robert |url= http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3Afea956a2-94a3-4110-a4d2-880ae0b7d3bd |title=J-20 Completes First Flight|work=Aviation Week & Space Technology|accessdate=30 June 2011}} After the successful flight, a ceremony was held, attended by the pilot, Li Gang, Chief Designer Yang Wei and General Li Andong, Deputy-Director of General Armaments.[http://airforceworld.com/pla/j20-stealth-fighter-first-flight-celebration.htm "Chinese J-20 Fighter First Flight Ceremony."] ''AirForceWorld.com''. Retrieved 15 March 2011. On 17 April 2011, a second test flight of an hour and 20 minutes took place.{{Cite news|url= http://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE73I0FQ20110419 |title=China stealth fighter "appears" to have made second flight|agency=Reuters|accessdate=21 August 2012}} On 5 May 2011, a 55-minute test flight was held that included retraction of the landing gear.[http://www.china-defense-mashup.com/chinese-j-20-stealth-fighter-makes-third-test-flight-landing-gears-folded.html "Chinese J-20 stealth fighter makes third flight; landing gears folded."] ''China Defence Mashup'', 5 May 2011. On 26 February 2012, a J-20 performed various low-altitude maneuvers.{{cite web|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E-zL42UKrnI |title=Video: J-20 Combat Maneuver Tests |publisher= Google | work = YouTube |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2013}} On 10 May 2012, a second prototype underwent high speed taxiing tests, and flight testing that began later that month.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTyIB6vUZNo "Video: J-20 Prototype 2002 Ground Tests."] ''YouTube''. 30 May 2012. Retrieved 25 February 2014.{{Cite web |last= Axe |first=David|url=http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2012/05/china-new-stealth-fighter/ |title=China Flies New Stealth Fighter as Problems Plague U.S. Jets|work=Wired|date=16 May 2012}} On 20 October 2012, photographs of a new prototype emerged, featuring a different radome, which was speculated to house an [[Active electronically scanned array|AESA]] radar. On March 2013, images of the side weapon bays appeared, including a missile launch rail.{{cite web|url= http://complex.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2012/10/23/chinas_stealth_fighter_program_keeps_moving_forward |title= This might be China's third J-20 stealth fighter|work=Foreign Policy |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2013}}{{Cite web|last=Cenciotti |first=David|url=http://theaviationist.com/2013/03/26/j20-rails/ |title=China's new stealth fighter's missile launch rails prove Beijing can improve U.S. technology |work=The Aviationist|date=26 March 2013|accessdate=10 May 2013}}[http://baike.baidu.com/view/4996396.htm?fromId=5002969 "J-20."] ''Baidu''. Retrieved 25 February 2014. On 16 January 2014, a J-20 prototype was revealed, showing a new intake and stealth coating, as well as redesigned vertical stabilizers, and an [[Electro-Optical Targeting System]].{{cite web |url= https://medium.com/war-is-boring/6b8ebf775795 |title=China’s Latest Stealth Fighter Prototype Has, Well, Actual Stealth Features. |last1=Axe |first1=David |website=medium.com |accessdate=17 January 2014}}[http://theaviationist.com/2014/02/21/j-20-2011-ready/ "Upgraded, third prototype."] ''The Aviationist'', 21 February 2014[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=evfbbOgJ9cY "J-20 Prototype 2011 Taxi Test."] ''Youtube''. Retrieved 24 February 2014. This particular aircraft, numbered '2011', performed its maiden flight on 1 March 2014 and is said to represent the initial pre-serial standard. By the end of 2014, three more pre-serial prototypes were flown: number '2012' on 26 July 2014, number '2013' on 29 November 2014 and finally number '2015' on 19 December 2014. On 13 September 2015, a new prototype, marked '2016', begun testing. It had noticeable improvements, such as apparently changed DSI bumps on the intakes, which save weight, complexity and radar signature. The DSI changes suggested the possibility of more powerful engines being used than on its predecessors, likely to be an advanced 14-ton thrust derivative of the Russian [[AL-31]] or Chinese [[Shenyang WS-10]] turbofan engines, though, by 2020 the J-20 is planned to use the 18-19 ton [[WS-15]] engine, enabling the jet to super-cruise without using afterburners. The trapezoidal flight booms around the engines were enlarged, possibly to accommodate rearwards facing radars or electronic jamming equipment. The fuselage extends almost entirely up to the engine's exhaust nozzles. Compared to its "2014" and "2015" predecessors, the J-20's fuselage contains more of engine's surface area inside the stealthy fuselage, providing greater rear-facing stealth against enemy radar.{{Citation | url = http://www.popsci.com/stealthier-stealth-seventh-upgraded-chinese-stealth-fighter-prototype-aims-to-take-flight | title = Stealthier stealth: seventh upgraded Chinese stealth fighter prototype aims to take flight | newspaper = Popular sciende}}. In November 2015, a new J-20 prototype, numbered '2017', took to the sky. The most significant change in the new prototype is the reshaped cockpit canopy, which provides the pilot with greater visibility. The lack of other design changes suggest that "2017" is very close to the final J-20 production configuration. Since '2017' is likely the last J-20 prototype, low rate initial production of the J-20 is likely to begin in 2016.http://www.popsci.com/2017-prototype-heralds-end-an-era-for-j-20-fighter-jet-testing-start-another-era It has been reported that the design of J-20 is already mature and will not directly use the 117S engine.{{Citation |contribution = Mil |title = News |publisher = Sina |date = 25 November 2015 |contribution-url = http://mil.news.sina.com.cn/2015-11-25/0848844774.html}} ===Production=== In late December 2015, a new J-20 numbered 2101 was spotted; it is believed to be the low rate initial production (LRIP) version of the aircraft.{{cite web | language = zh |url= http://news.ifeng.com/a/20151226/46845415_0.shtml |title= 新歼-20照片曝光 黄皮机身编号2101或已开始量产 |publisher= Ifeng |date=26 December 2015 |accessdate=26 December 2015}} That aircraft performed its maiden flight on 18 January 2016.http://plarealtalk.com/2016/01/27/j-20-first-lrip-airframe-maiden-flight-serial-number-2101/ ==Design== ===Characteristics=== [[File:J-20_2011.jpg|thumb|Chengdu J-20 side view]] [[File:Chengdu J-20.svg|thumb|Chengdu J-20 prototype]] The J-20 has a long and wide [[fuselage]], with the chiseled [[Nose cone|nose section]] and a [[bubble canopy|frameless canopy]] resembling that of the F-22 Raptor. Immediately behind the cockpit are low observable intakes. All-moving [[Canard (aeronautics)|canard]] surfaces with pronounced dihedral are placed behind the intakes, followed by [[Leading-edge extension|leading edge extensions]] merging into [[delta wing]] with forward-swept trailing edges. The aft section features twin, outward canted all-moving fins, short but deep ventral strakes, and conventional round engine exhausts.[http://learn.digitalglobe.com/lp/worldviewreport/worldviewreport-vol15.html "Worldview Report | Vol. 14"] {{wayback|url=http://learn.digitalglobe.com/lp/worldviewreport/worldviewreport-vol15.html |date=20130104005858 |df=y }} ''digitalglobe.com'' 2 January 2013 One important design criterion for the J-20 describes [[Relaxed stability|high instability]]. This requires sustained pitch authority at a high angle of attack, in which a conventional tail-plane would lose effectiveness due to [[Stall (aerodynamics)|stalling]]. On the other hand, a canard can deflect opposite to the angle of attack, avoiding stall and thereby maintaining control.[https://www.google.com/patents/EP0202020A1?cl=en "Super Agile aircraft and method of flying it in supernormal flight."] ''Google Patents''. Retrieved 20 March 2013 A canard design is also known to provide good supersonic performance, excellent supersonic and transonic turn performance, and improved short-field landing performance compared to the conventional delta wing design.Probert, B. [http://ftp.rta.nato.int/public//PubFulltext/RTO/EN/RTO-EN-004///$EN-004-19.pdf "Aspects of Wing Design for Transonic and Supersonic Combat."] {{wayback|url=http://ftp.rta.nato.int/public/ |date=20110517202722 |df=y }} ''NATO.'' Retrieved: 23 January 2011.Neblett, Evan et al. [http://www.aoe.vt.edu/~mason/Mason_f/canardsS03.pdf "Canards."] ''AOE 4124: Configuration Aerodynamics'', ''Department of Aerospace and Ocean Engineering, Virginia Tech'', 17 March 2003. Retrieved: 28 November 2009. [[Leading edge extension]]s and [[Lifting body|body lift]] are incorporated to enhance performance in a canard layout. This combination is said by the designer to generate 1.2 times the lift of an ordinary canard delta, and 1.8 times more lift than an equivalent sized pure delta configuration. The designer claims such a combination allows the use of a smaller wing, reducing supersonic drag without compromising transonic lift-to-drag characteristics that are crucial to the aircraft's turn performance.[http://ishare.iask.sina.com.cn/f/23321633.html "一种小展弦比高升力飞机的气动布局研究 A High Lift Low-Aspect Ratio Aerodynamic Configuration"] ''sina.com'' Retrieved 20 March 2013[http://www.defence.pk/forums/chinese-defence/165231-translation-j-20-article-dr-song-wencong.html "Translation of article 一种小展弦比高升力飞机的气动布局研究"] ''http://www.defence.pk''{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Retrieved 20 March 2013[http://wenku.baidu.com/view/1aae34a6f524ccbff12184b3.html "一种小展弦比高升力飞机的气动布局研究 A High Lift Low-Aspect Ratio Aerodynamic Configuration"] ''baidu.com'' Retrieved 20 March 2013 According to the [[Jamestown Foundation]], the J-20 has the potential for development into a high performance stealth aircraft comparable to the F-22 Raptor, if given appropriate engines.[http://www.jamestown.org/programs/chinabrief/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=37903&cHash=388055c494bacab998da29dfe56c08a0 "An Initial Assessment of China's J-20 Stealth Fighter."] ''The Jamestown Foundation'', 6 May 2011 ===Engines=== The prototype is believed to be initially powered by [[Shenyang WS-10|WS-10]] and / or the [[Saturn AL-31|AL-31F]] engines. China is currently working on an advanced domestic turbofan engine similar in performance to the Pratt & Whitney [[F119]] coded WS-15,http://www.defensenews.com/article/20121119/DEFFEAT05/311190005/Deterring-China-8217-s-Fighter-Buildup?odyssey=nav%7Chead but there are also speculations that [[Saturn AL-31#117S]] engine may be used for the initial batch of the J-20.{{Cite web|last=Kopp|first=Carlo|url=http://www.jamestown.org/programs/chinabrief/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=37903&cHash=388055c494bacab998da29dfe56c08a0|title=An Initial Assessment of China's J-20 Stealth Fighter|work=The Jamestown Foundation|date=6 May 2011}}{{Cite news|last=Johnson|first=Reuben F.|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/25/chinas-development-of-fighter-jets-relies-on-russi/ |title=China’s development of fighter jets relies on Russian systems|newspaper=Washington Times|date=25 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/china-buys-su-35s-engines-for-j-20-2012-11|title=China Buys Su-35s - Business Insider|date=28 November 2012|work=Business Insider|accessdate=4 February 2015}} At the 2012 Zhuhai Air Show, Russia approached China in an unsuccessful bid to sell the Su-35, which included the 117S engines.[http://sky.news.sina.com.cn/2012-11-13/154829147.html "俄军企称希望向中国出口117S大推力发动机"] ''sina.com'' 5 December 2012 According to the latest news, China and Russia signed a contract for 24 Su-35 in November, 2015.https://www.rt.com/news/322659-china-russia-su35-deal/ However, Chinese source stated that the design of J-20 is mature and it will not directly use 117S engine. The production version of the J-20 is believed to be powered by the [[WS-15]], a turbofan engine currently under development.[http://www.turbineengine.org/pdf/China%20Aerospace%20Propulsion%20Technology%20Summit.pdf "China Aerospace Propulsion Technology Summit."]. ''International Aircraft Engine Association'', 19 June 2012.Fisher, Richard, Jr. [http://www.strategycenter.net/research/pubID.219/pub_detail.asp "October Surprises in Chinese Aerospace."] ''International Assessment and Strategy Center'', 9 January 2013 According to Global Security, the engine core, composed of high pressure compressors, the combustion chamber, and high pressure turbines were successfully tested in 2005.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/china/ws15.htm "WS-15"] ''Global Security'', 11 July 2011 An image of the core appeared in the 2006 Zhuhai Air Show.{{cite web|url=http://thediplomat.com/2012/12/07/the-long-pole-in-the-tent-chinas-military-jet-engines/ |title=The 'Long Pole in the Tent': China’s Military Jet Engines. |publisher=''The Diplomat'' |date=7 December 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://focustaiwan.tw/ShowNews/WebNews_Detail.aspx?Type=aALL&ID=201212210039 |title=China makes progress in developing alloy for airplane engines. |publisher=''Focustaiwan.tw'' |date=21 December 2012 |accessdate=10 June 2013}}[http://news.chinatungsten.com/en/tungsten-product-news/299-tpn-61 "China Has Made Great Breakthrough in High-temperature Alloy to Biggest Military Jet Engine."] ''news.chinatungsten.com'' ===Avionics and cockpit=== [[File:J20 2.jpg|thumb|The J-20 has an IRST at its nose]] The aircraft features a [[glass cockpit]], with two main large color [[liquid crystal display]]s (LCD) situated side-by-side, three smaller auxiliary displays, and a wide-angle holographic [[head-up display]] (HUD).[http://media.aerosociety.com/aerospace-insight/2011/01/14/not-so-hidden-dragon-j-20-assessed/3524/ "Not so hidden dragon – China’s J-20 assessed."] {{wayback|url=http://media.aerosociety.com/aerospace-insight/2011/01/14/not-so-hidden-dragon-j-20-assessed/3524/ |date=20130405044029 |df=y }} ''Royal Aeronautical Society''. Retrieved 20 December 2012.{{dl|date=November 2016}}[http://defensetech.org/2012/06/01/pic-of-the-week-the-j-20s-hud/ "Photo: China’s J-20 Stealth Fighter Head-On."] ''defensetech.org''. Retrieved 20 December 2012.[http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2012/06/is-china-stealing-americas-top-stealth-fighter-jet-secrets/ "Is China Stealing America’s Top Stealth Fighter Jet Secrets?"] ''GIZMODO Australia''. Retrieved 20 December 2012. A [[People's Liberation Army Air Force|PLAAF]] [[Tupolev Tu-204]] testbed aircraft featured a J-20 nose cone. It is believed to house the '''Type 1475''' (KLJ-5) [[active electronically scanned array]] (AESA) radar with 1856 [[Transceiver|transmit/receive]] modules.{{cite web|url=http://www.popsci.com/blog-network/eastern-arsenal/stealth-radar-tests-passenger-jet?dom=PSC&loc=recent&lnk=2&con=-stealth-radar-tests-on-passenger-jet|title=Stealth Radar Tests on Passenger Jet|work=Popular Science|accessdate=4 February 2015}} Prototype "2011" featured a revised nose section with elements resembling a [[IRST]]/[[Electro-Optical Targeting System|EOTS]] system, and a metal finish that loosely resembles the radar absorbing Haze Paint first used on [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16s]],{{cn|date=November 2016}} and reportedly included sensor fusion technology.{{cite web |last=Cenciotti |first=David |url=http://theaviationist.com/2014/02/21/j-20-2011-ready |title=Upgraded, third prototype of China’s stealth jet ready for maiden flight |website=The Aviationist |date=21 February 2014 |accessdate=24 January 2015}} Chinese company [[Agency for Science, Technology and Research|A-Star Science and Technology]] has developed the EOTS-89 electro-optical targeting system and EORD-31 [[Infra-red search and track|IRST]] for the J-20 and potentially other PLAAF fighters to detect and intercept stealth aircraft. ===Armament=== The main weapon bay is capable of housing both short and long-range [[air-to-air missile]]s (AAM) ([[PL-9]], [[PL-12]]C/D &PL15 - [[PL-21]]). Two smaller lateral weapon bays behind the air inlets are intended for short-range AAMs (PL-9). These bays allow closure of the bay doors prior to firing the missile, thus enhancing stealth.[http://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/ain-defense-perspective/2013-04-05/china-claims-innovation-j-20-weapons-bay-design "China claims innovation in J-20 weapons bay design"] ''AINonline'', Retrieved March 2, 2014[[Bill Sweetman|Sweetman, Bill]]. "[http://aviationweek.com/defense/j-20-stealth-fighter-design-balances-speed-and-agility J-20 Stealth Fighter Design Balances Speed And Agility]" ''[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]'', 3 November 2014. Accessed: 5 November 2014. [https://web.archive.org/web/20141105012355/http://aviationweek.com/defense/j-20-stealth-fighter-design-balances-speed-and-agility Archived] on 5 November 2014 ===Stealth=== Analysts noted that the J-20's nose and canopy use a similar stealth shaping design as the [[F-22]], yielding similar signature performance in a mature design at the front, while the aircraft's side and axi-symmetric engine nozzles may expose the aircraft to radar.{{Cite web |last1=Kopp|first1=Carlo|first2=Peter|last2=Goon|url=http://www.ausairpower.net/APA-J-XX-Prototype.html |title=Chengdu J-XX Stealth Fighter Prototype |work=[[Air Power Australia]]|date=1 January 2011}}Axe, David. [http://www.warisboring.com/2010/12/29/chengdu-j-20-chinas-first-stealth-fighter/ "Chengdu J-20: China’s First Stealth Fighter."] {{wayback|url=http://www.warisboring.com/2010/12/29/chengdu-j-20-chinas-first-stealth-fighter/ |date=20110101092821 |df=y }} ''warisboring.com'', 29 December 2010. One prototype has been powered by WS-10G engines equipped with a different [[serration|jagged-edge]] nozzles and tiles for greater stealth. Others have raised doubts about the use of canards on a low-observable design, stating that canards would guarantee radar detection and a compromise of stealth.Waldron, Greg. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/01/04/351462/long-march-chinas-fifth-generation-fighter-is-years.html "Long March: China’s fifth-generation fighter is years away."] ''Flight International''. Retrieved 23 January 2011.Hodge, Nathan. [http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2011/01/19/chinas-j-20-fighter-stealthy-or-just-stealthy-looking/ "China’s J-20 Fighter: Stealthy or Just Stealthy-Looking?"] ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 19 January 2011. However, canards and low-observability are not mutually exclusive designs. Northrop Grumman's proposal for the U.S. Navy's [[Advanced Tactical Fighter]] (ATF) incorporated canards on a stealthy airframe.[http://www.yf-23.net/F-23A.html "F-23A & NATF-23"] ''yf-23.net'', 15 January 2013[http://www.aerospaceprojectsreview.com/blog/?p=360 "NATF-23 diagram in hi-rez."] ''Aerospace Project Review'' 15 January 2013. Lockheed Martin employed canards on a stealth airframe for the [[Joint Strike Fighter program|Joint Advanced Strike Technology (JAST)]] program during early development before dropping them due to complications with aircraft carrier recovery.Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A5c50cb01-bdd0-41cc-b216-fdc89354eb19 "From JAST To J-20".] ''Aviation Week'', 14 January 2011.Sweetman 2005, p. 122–124. McDonnell Douglas and NASA's [[X-36]] featured canards and was considered to be extremely stealthy.[http://www.designnews.com/document.asp?doc_id=220162&dfpPParams=ind_182,industry_aero,aid_220162&dfpLayout=article "Agility+Stealth = X-36: formula for an advanced fighter "] ''Design News''. 14 January 2013 [[Radar cross-section]] can be further reduced by controlling canard deflection through flight control software, as is done on the [[Eurofighter]].[https://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A%2F%2Feurofighter.airpower.at%2Ffaq.htm&langpair=de%7Cen&hl=en&ie=UTF-8 "Faq Eurofighter (translation)"]. Retrieved 29 November 2009.Rosenkranz, Martin. [https://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.airpower.at%2Fforum%2Fviewtopic.php%3Ft%3D2629&langpair=de%7Cen&hl=en&ie=UTF-8 "Austrian Eurofighter committee of inquiry."] pp. 76–77. (English translation). ''Google''. Retrieved 28 November 2009. The [[diverterless supersonic inlet]] (DSI) enables an aircraft to reach Mach 2.0 with a simpler intake than traditionally required, and improves stealth performance by eliminating radar reflections between the diverter and the aircraft's skin. Analysts have noted that the J-20 DSI reduces the need for application of [[Radar-absorbent material|radar absorbent materials]].Hehs, Eric. [http://www.codeonemagazine.com/article.html?item_id=58 "JSF Diverterless Supersonic Inlet."] ''[[LockMart]]'', 15 July 2000.[http://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckBlogId=Blog:27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog:27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post:2bbb8a32-8bf4-47c5-86c4-48f3c78e53c2 "J-20's Stealth Signature Poses Interesting Unknowns."] ''Aviation Week''. Retrieved 13 January 2013 Additionally, the "bump" surface reduces the engine's exposure to radar, significantly reducing a strong source of radar reflection.[http://aviationintel.com/2012/10/22/fast-history-lockheeds-diverterless-supersonic-inlet-testbed-f-16/ "Fast History: Lockheed's Diverterless Supersonic Inlet Testbed F-16"] {{wayback|url=http://aviationintel.com/2012/10/22/fast-history-lockheeds-diverterless-supersonic-inlet-testbed-f-16/ |date=20130907000042 |df=y }} ''aviationintel.com'', 13 January 2013 ==Strategic implications== ===Political=== The first test flight coincided with a visit by [[United States Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] to China, and was initially interpreted by the Pentagon as a possible signal to the visiting U.S. delegation. Speaking to reporters in Beijing, secretary Gates said "I asked President Hu about it directly, and he said that the test had absolutely nothing to do with my visit and there had been a pre-planned test."{{Citation | last1 = Erickson | first1 = Andrew | first2 = Gabe | last2 = Collins | quote = China plans to have at least 500 to 700 J-20 fighter jet before 2035 to challenge USA's F-35 | url = http://www.andrewerickson.com/2011/01/j-20-fighter-development-outlook-strategic-implications/ | title = China’s New J-20 Fighter: Development Outlook and Strategic Implications | publisher = Andrew Erickson | date = 17 January 2011 | accessdate = 23 January 2011}}.Wines, Michael and Elisabeth Bumiller. [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/13/world/asia/13fighter.html?ref=asia "Test Unrelated to Gates Visit, China Says."] ''The New York Times'', 12 January 2011. Retrieved 13 January 2011. President Hu seemed surprised by Gates' inquiry, prompting speculations that the test might have been a signal sent unilaterally by the Chinese military.{{Cite news|last=Barnes |first= Julian E.|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703947404576076941991898836.html?mod=WSJ_World_MIDDLENews |title=Gates, China Discuss Nuclear Strategy |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=12 January 2011|accessdate=12 January 2011}}{{Cite news |last=Stewart |first=Phil|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE70A19B20110111 |title=Gates: China confirms stealth jet test-flight|agency=Reuters |date=11 January 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}Bumiller, Elisabeth and Michael Wines. [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/12/world/asia/12fighter.html "Test of Stealth Fighter Clouds Gates Visit to China."] ''The New York Times'', 11 January 2011. Abraham M. Denmark of the Center for New American Security in Washington, along with [[Michael D. Swaine|Michael Swaine]], an expert on the [[People's Liberation Army|PLA]] and [[China–United States relations#Military spending and planning|United States–China military relations]], explained that senior officials are not involved in day-to-day management of aircraft development and were unaware of the test. ===Military=== [[Robert Gates]] downplayed the significance of the aircraft by questioning how stealthy the J-20 may be, but stated the J-20 would "put some of our capabilities at risk, and we have to pay attention to them, we have to respond appropriately with our own programs."Bumiller, Elisabeth. [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/09/world/asia/09military.html "U.S. Will Counter Chinese Arms Buildup."] ''[[The New York Times]]'', 8 January 2011. The U.S. Director of National Intelligence [[James R. Clapper]] testified that the United States knew about the program for a long time and that the test flight was not a surprise.Clapper, James R. [http://intelligence.house.gov/hearing/full-committee-world-wide-threats-hearing "World Wide Threats Hearing"] {{wayback|url=http://intelligence.house.gov/hearing/full-committee-world-wide-threats-hearing |date=20110203054417 |df=y }} ''Director of National Intelligence'', 10 February 2011. [[Lexington Institute|Loren B. Thompson]] felt that J-20's combination of forward stealth and long range puts America's surface assets at risk, and that a long-range maritime strike capability may cause the United States more concern than a short range air-superiority fighter like the F-22.{{Cite web |last= Majumdar |first=Dave|url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2011/02/air-force-deptula-calls-j20-a-wake-up-call-021311w/ |title=J-20 a ‘wake-up call,’ former intel chief says|work= AirForce Times |date= 13 February 2011}}Thompson, Loren B. [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/chinese-fighter-test-embarrasses-gates-casts-doubt-on-goals?a=1&c=1171 "Chinese Fighter Test Embarrasses Gates, Casts Doubt On Goals."] ''[[Lexington Institute]]'', 13 January 2011. In its 2011 Annual Report to Congress, the Pentagon described the J-20 as "a platform capable of long range, penetrating strikes into complex air defense environments."[http://www.defense.gov/pubs/pdfs/2011_cmpr_final.pdf "Annual Report to Congress: Military and Security Developments Involving the People’s Republic of China, 2011."] ''Office of the Secretary of Defense,'' 6 May 2011. Retrieved 16 February 2012. A 2012 report by the U.S.‐China Economic and Security Review Commission suggests that the United States may have underestimated the speed of development of the J-20 and several other Chinese military development projects.[http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2012/China-Indigenous-Military-Developments-Final-Draft-03-April2012.pdf "Indigenous Weapons Development in China’s Military Modernization."] {{wayback|url=http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2012/China-Indigenous-Military-Developments-Final-Draft-03-April2012.pdf |date=20120417073858 |df=y }} ''U.S.–China Economic and Security Review Commission Staff Research Report,'' 2012. Observers are not able to reach a consensus on J-20's primary role.{{cite web|last1=Gresham|first1=John D. |title= J-20 Assessment: Not So Fast!|url=http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/j-20-assessment-not-so-fast/ |website=Defense Media Network|publisher=Faircount Media Group|accessdate=11 October 2015|date=1 February 2011}}{{cite web|last =Cole|first = J. Michael|title= China Developing a 2nd Stealth Fighter? The rumored J-21 "Snowy Owl" would be China’s second stealth aircraft project, along with the J-20 |url= http://thediplomat.com/2012/08/china-developing-a-2nd-stealth-fighter/ | work =The Diplomat |accessdate= 11 October 2015|date=6 August 2012}}{{cite web|last =Majumdar |first =Dave |title= America's F-22 Raptor vs. China's Stealth J-20: Who Wins?|url=http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/americas-f-22-raptor-vs-chinas-stealth-j-20-who-wins-13813|website=The National Interest|publisher=Center for The National Interest |accessdate= 11 October 2015|date=10 September 2015}} Based on initial photographs with focus on the aircraft's size, early speculations referred to the J-20 as an [[F-111]] equivalent with little to no [[air superiority fighter|air-to-air]] ability. Others saw the J-20 as a potential [[air superiority fighter]] once appropriate engines become available.{{Cite web|last=Kopp|first=Carlo|url=http://www.ausairpower.net/APA-NOTAM-090111-1.html|title= The Strategic Impact of China's J-XX Stealth Fighter|work=[[Air Power Australia]] |date=9 January 2011}} More recent speculations refer to the J-20 as an air-to-air fighter with an emphasis on forward stealth, high-speed aerodynamics, range, and adequate agility. The J-20 could threaten vulnerable tankers and ISR/C2 platforms, depriving Washington of radar coverage and strike range. However one of these targets, the [[Northrop Grumman E-2 Hawkeye]], is reported to be optimized for spotting fighter sized stealth aircraft such as the J-20.{{cite news |url=https://news.usni.org/2014/06/09/u-s-navys-secret-counter-stealth-weapon-hiding-plain-sight |title=The U.S. Navy’s Secret Counter-Stealth Weapon Could Be Hiding in Plain Sight |last1=Majumdar |first1=Dave |date=0 June 2014 |website=news.usni.org |publisher=U.S. NAVAL INSTITUTE |accessdate=4 November 2016}} ===Cyber security=== In April 2009, a ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' report indicated that, according to the Pentagon, information from the [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II]] had been compromised by unknown attackers that appeared to originate from China. There is some speculation that the compromise of the F-35 program may have helped in the development of the J-20.Groman, Siobhan, August Cole and [[Yochi Dreazen]]. [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB124027491029837401.html "Computer Spies Breach Fighter-Jet Project."] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', 21 April 2009.
